originalTools.name: analytics-mcp__get_account_summaries
originalTools.description: Retrieves information about the user's Google Analytics accounts and properties.

originalTools.name: analytics-mcp__list_google_ads_links
originalTools.description:
Returns a list of links to Google Ads accounts for a property.

Args:
    property_id: The Google Analytics property ID. Accepted formats are:
      - A number
      - A string consisting of 'properties/' followed by a number

originalTools.name: analytics-mcp__get_property_details
originalTools.description:
Returns details about a property.
Args:
    property_id: The Google Analytics property ID. Accepted formats are:
      - A number
      - A string consisting of 'properties/' followed by a number

originalTools.name: analytics-mcp__get_custom_dimensions_and_metrics
originalTools.description:
Returns the property's custom dimensions and metrics.

Args:
    property_id: The Google Analytics property ID. Accepted formats are:
      - A number
      - A string consisting of 'properties/' followed by a number

originalTools.name: analytics-mcp__run_realtime_report
originalTools.description:
Runs a Google Analytics Data API realtime report.

See
https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/reporting/data/v1/realtime-basics
for more information.

Args:
    property_id: The Google Analytics property ID. Accepted formats are:
      - A number
      - A string consisting of 'properties/' followed by a number
    dimensions: A list of dimensions to include in the report. Dimensions must be realtime dimensions.
    metrics: A list of metrics to include in the report. Metrics must be realtime metrics.
    dimension_filter: A Data API FilterExpression
      (https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/reporting/data/v1/rest/v1beta/FilterExpression)
      to apply to the dimensions.  Don't use this for filtering metrics. Use
      metric_filter instead. The `field_name` in a `dimension_filter` must
      be a dimension, as defined in the `get_standard_dimensions` and
      `get_dimensions` tools.
      For more information about the expected format of this argument, see
      the `run_report_dimension_filter_hints` tool.
    metric_filter: A Data API FilterExpression
      (https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/reporting/data/v1/rest/v1beta/FilterExpression)
      to apply to the metrics.  Don't use this for filtering dimensions. Use
      dimension_filter instead. The `field_name` in a `metric_filter` must
      be a metric, as defined in the `get_standard_metrics` and
      `get_metrics` tools.
      For more information about the expected format of this argument, see
      the `run_report_metric_filter_hints` tool.
    order_bys: A list of Data API OrderBy
      (https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/reporting/data/v1/rest/v1beta/OrderBy)
      objects to apply to the dimensions and metrics.
      For more information about the expected format of this argument, see
      the `run_report_order_bys_hints` tool.
    limit: The maximum number of rows to return in each response. Value must
      be a positive integer <= 250,000. Used to paginate through large
      reports, following the guide at
      https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/reporting/data/v1/basics#pagination.
    offset: The row count of the start row. The first row is counted as row
      0. Used to paginate through large
      reports, following the guide at
      https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/reporting/data/v1/basics#pagination.
    return_property_quota: Whether to return realtime property quota in the response.


          ## Hints for arguments

          Here are some hints that outline the expected format and requirements
          for arguments.

          ### Hints for `dimensions`

          The `dimensions` list must consist solely of either of the following:

          1.  Realtime standard dimensions defined in the HTML table at
              https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/reporting/data/v1/realtime-api-schema#dimensions.
              These dimensions are available to *every* property.
          2.  User-scoped custom dimensions for the `property_id`. Use the
              `get_custom_dimensions_and_metrics` tool to retrieve the list of
              custom dimensions for a property, and look for the custom
              dimensions with an `apiName` that begins with "customUser:".

          ### Hints for `metrics`

          The `metrics` list must consist solely of the Realtime standard
          metrics defined in the HTML table at
          https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/reporting/data/v1/realtime-api-schema#metrics.
          These metrics are available to *every* property.

          Realtime reports can't use custom metrics.

          ### Hints for `date_ranges`:
          Example date_range arguments:
      1. A single date range:

        [ {"start_date": "2025-01-01", "end_date": "2025-01-31", "name": "Jan2025"} ]

      2. A relative date range using 'yesterday' and 'today':
        [ {"start_date": "yesterday", "end_date": "today", "name": "YesterdayAndToday"} ]

      3. A relative date range using 'NdaysAgo' and 'today':
        [ {"start_date": "30daysAgo", "end_date": "yesterday", "name": "Previous30Days"}]

      4. Multiple date ranges:
        [ {"start_date": "2025-01-01", "end_date": "2025-01-31", "name": "Jan2025"}, {"start_date": "2025-02-01", "end_date": "2025-02-28", "name": "Feb2025"} ]
    

          ### Hints for `dimension_filter`:
          Example dimension_filter arguments:
      1. A simple filter:
        {"filter": {"field_name": "eventName", "string_filter": {"match_type": 2, "value": "add", "case_sensitive": false}}}

      2. A NOT filter:
        {"not_expression": {"filter": {"field_name": "eventName", "string_filter": {"match_type": 2, "value": "add", "case_sensitive": false}}}}

      3. An empty value filter:
        {"filter": {"field_name": "source", "empty_filter": {}}}

      4. An AND group filter:
        {"and_group": {"expressions": [{"filter": {"field_name": "sourceMedium", "string_filter": {"match_type": 1, "value": "google / cpc", "case_sensitive": false}}}, {"filter": {"field_name": "eventName", "in_list_filter": {"values": ["first_visit", "purchase", "add_to_cart"], "case_sensitive": true}}}]}}

      5. An OR group filter:
        {"or_group": {"expressions": [{"filter": {"field_name": "sourceMedium", "string_filter": {"match_type": 1, "value": "google / cpc", "case_sensitive": false}}}, {"filter": {"field_name": "eventName", "in_list_filter": {"values": ["first_visit", "purchase", "add_to_cart"], "case_sensitive": true}}}]}}

    
  Notes:
    The API applies the `dimension_filter` and `metric_filter`
    independently. As a result, some complex combinations of dimension and
    metric filters are not possible in a single report request.

    For example, you can't create a `dimension_filter` and `metric_filter`
    combination for the following condition:

    (
      (eventName = "page_view" AND eventCount > 100)
      OR
      (eventName = "join_group" AND eventCount < 50)
    )

    This isn't possible because there's no way to apply the condition
    "eventCount > 100" only to the data with eventName of "page_view", and
    the condition "eventCount < 50" only to the data with eventName of
    "join_group".

    More generally, you can't define a `dimension_filter` and `metric_filter`
    for:

    (
      ((dimension condition D1) AND (metric condition M1))
      OR
      ((dimension condition D2) AND (metric condition M2))
    )

    If you have complex conditions like this, either:

    a)  Run a single report that applies a subset of the conditions that
        the API supports as well as the data needed to perform filtering of the
        API response on the client side. For example, for the condition:
        (
          (eventName = "page_view" AND eventCount > 100)
          OR
          (eventName = "join_group" AND eventCount < 50)
        )
        You could run a report that filters only on:
        eventName one of "page_view" or "join_group"
        and include the eventCount metric, then filter the API response on the
        client side to apply the different metric filters for the different
        events.

    or

    b)  Run a separate report for each combination of dimension condition and
        metric condition. For the example above, you'd run one report for the
        combination of (D1 AND M1), and another report for the combination of
        (D2 AND M2).

    Try to run fewer reports (option a) if possible. However, if running
    fewer reports results in excessive quota usage for the API, use option
    b. More information on quota usage is at
    https://developers.google.com/analytics/blog/2023/data-api-quota-management.
  

          ### Hints for `metric_filter`:
          Example metric_filter arguments:
      1. A simple filter:
        {"filter": {"field_name": "eventCount", "numeric_filter": {"operation": 4, "value": {"int64_value": "10"}}}}

      2. A NOT filter:
        {"not_expression": {"filter": {"field_name": "eventCount", "numeric_filter": {"operation": 4, "value": {"int64_value": "10"}}}}}

      3. An empty value filter:
        {"filter": {"field_name": "purchaseRevenue", "empty_filter": {}}}

      4. An AND group filter:
        {"and_group": {"expressions": [{"filter": {"field_name": "eventCount", "numeric_filter": {"operation": 4, "value": {"int64_value": "10"}}}}, {"filter": {"field_name": "purchaseRevenue", "between_filter": {"from_value": {"double_value": 10.0}, "to_value": {"double_value": 25.0}}}}]}}

      5. An OR group filter:
        {"or_group": {"expressions": [{"filter": {"field_name": "eventCount", "numeric_filter": {"operation": 4, "value": {"int64_value": "10"}}}}, {"filter": {"field_name": "purchaseRevenue", "between_filter": {"from_value": {"double_value": 10.0}, "to_value": {"double_value": 25.0}}}}]}}

    
  Notes:
    The API applies the `dimension_filter` and `metric_filter`
    independently. As a result, some complex combinations of dimension and
    metric filters are not possible in a single report request.

    For example, you can't create a `dimension_filter` and `metric_filter`
    combination for the following condition:

    (
      (eventName = "page_view" AND eventCount > 100)
      OR
      (eventName = "join_group" AND eventCount < 50)
    )

    This isn't possible because there's no way to apply the condition
    "eventCount > 100" only to the data with eventName of "page_view", and
    the condition "eventCount < 50" only to the data with eventName of
    "join_group".

    More generally, you can't define a `dimension_filter` and `metric_filter`
    for:

    (
      ((dimension condition D1) AND (metric condition M1))
      OR
      ((dimension condition D2) AND (metric condition M2))
    )

    If you have complex conditions like this, either:

    a)  Run a single report that applies a subset of the conditions that
        the API supports as well as the data needed to perform filtering of the
        API response on the client side. For example, for the condition:
        (
          (eventName = "page_view" AND eventCount > 100)
          OR
          (eventName = "join_group" AND eventCount < 50)
        )
        You could run a report that filters only on:
        eventName one of "page_view" or "join_group"
        and include the eventCount metric, then filter the API response on the
        client side to apply the different metric filters for the different
        events.

    or

    b)  Run a separate report for each combination of dimension condition and
        metric condition. For the example above, you'd run one report for the
        combination of (D1 AND M1), and another report for the combination of
        (D2 AND M2).

    Try to run fewer reports (option a) if possible. However, if running
    fewer reports results in excessive quota usage for the API, use option
    b. More information on quota usage is at
    https://developers.google.com/analytics/blog/2023/data-api-quota-management.
  

          ### Hints for `order_bys`:
          Example order_bys arguments:

    1.  Order by ascending 'eventName':
        [ {"dimension": {"dimension_name": "eventName", "order_type": 1}, "desc": false} ]

    2.  Order by descending 'eventName', ignoring case:
        [ {"dimension": {"dimension_name": "campaignName", "order_type": 2}, "desc": true} ]

    3.  Order by ascending 'audienceId':
        [ {"dimension": {"dimension_name": "audienceId", "order_type": 3}, "desc": false} ]

    4.  Order by descending 'eventCount':
        [ {"metric": {"metric_name": "eventValue"}, "desc": true} ]

    5.  Order by ascending 'eventCount':
        [ {"metric": {"metric_name": "eventCount"}, "desc": false} ]

    6.  Combination of dimension and metric order bys:
        [
          {"dimension": {"dimension_name": "eventName", "order_type": 1}, "desc": false},
          {"metric": {"metric_name": "eventValue"}, "desc": true},
        ]

    7.  Order by multiple dimensions and metrics:
        [
          {"dimension": {"dimension_name": "eventName", "order_type": 1}, "desc": false},
          {"dimension": {"dimension_name": "audienceId", "order_type": 3}, "desc": false},
          {"metric": {"metric_name": "eventValue"}, "desc": true},
        ]

    The dimensions and metrics in order_bys must also be present in the report
    request's "dimensions" and "metrics" arguments, respectively.

originalTools.name: analytics-mcp__run_report
originalTools.description:
Runs a Google Analytics Data API report.

Note that the reference docs at
https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/reporting/data/v1/rest/v1beta
all use camelCase field names, but field names passed to this method should
be in snake_case since the tool is using the protocol buffers (protobuf)
format. The protocol buffers for the Data API are available at
https://github.com/googleapis/googleapis/tree/master/google/analytics/data/v1beta.

Args:
    property_id: The Google Analytics property ID. Accepted formats are:
      - A number
      - A string consisting of 'properties/' followed by a number
    date_ranges: A list of date ranges
      (https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/reporting/data/v1/rest/v1beta/DateRange)
      to include in the report.
    dimensions: A list of dimensions to include in the report.
    metrics: A list of metrics to include in the report.
    dimension_filter: A Data API FilterExpression
      (https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/reporting/data/v1/rest/v1beta/FilterExpression)
      to apply to the dimensions.  Don't use this for filtering metrics. Use
      metric_filter instead. The `field_name` in a `dimension_filter` must
      be a dimension, as defined in the `get_standard_dimensions` and
      `get_dimensions` tools.
    metric_filter: A Data API FilterExpression
      (https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/reporting/data/v1/rest/v1beta/FilterExpression)
      to apply to the metrics.  Don't use this for filtering dimensions. Use
      dimension_filter instead. The `field_name` in a `metric_filter` must
      be a metric, as defined in the `get_standard_metrics` and
      `get_metrics` tools.
    order_bys: A list of Data API OrderBy
      (https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/reporting/data/v1/rest/v1beta/OrderBy)
      objects to apply to the dimensions and metrics.
    limit: The maximum number of rows to return in each response. Value must
      be a positive integer <= 250,000. Used to paginate through large
      reports, following the guide at
      https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/reporting/data/v1/basics#pagination.
    offset: The row count of the start row. The first row is counted as row
      0. Used to paginate through large
      reports, following the guide at
      https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/reporting/data/v1/basics#pagination.
    currency_code: The currency code to use for currency values. Must be in
      ISO4217 format, such as "AED", "USD", "JPY". If the field is empty, the
      report uses the property's default currency.
    return_property_quota: Whether to return property quota in the response.


          ## Hints for arguments

          Here are some hints that outline the expected format and requirements
          for arguments.

          ### Hints for `dimensions`

          The `dimensions` list must consist solely of either of the following:

          1.  Standard dimensions defined in the HTML table at
              https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/reporting/data/v1/api-schema#dimensions.
              These dimensions are available to *every* property.
          2.  Custom dimensions for the `property_id`. Use the
              `get_custom_dimensions_and_metrics` tool to retrieve the list of
              custom dimensions for a property.

          ### Hints for `metrics`

          The `metrics` list must consist solely of either of the following:

          1.  Standard metrics defined in the HTML table at
              https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/reporting/data/v1/api-schema#metrics.
              These metrics are available to *every* property.
          2.  Custom metrics for the `property_id`. Use the
              `get_custom_dimensions_and_metrics` tool to retrieve the list of
              custom metrics for a property.


          ### Hints for `date_ranges`:
          Example date_range arguments:
      1. A single date range:

        [ {"start_date": "2025-01-01", "end_date": "2025-01-31", "name": "Jan2025"} ]

      2. A relative date range using 'yesterday' and 'today':
        [ {"start_date": "yesterday", "end_date": "today", "name": "YesterdayAndToday"} ]

      3. A relative date range using 'NdaysAgo' and 'today':
        [ {"start_date": "30daysAgo", "end_date": "yesterday", "name": "Previous30Days"}]

      4. Multiple date ranges:
        [ {"start_date": "2025-01-01", "end_date": "2025-01-31", "name": "Jan2025"}, {"start_date": "2025-02-01", "end_date": "2025-02-28", "name": "Feb2025"} ]
    

          ### Hints for `dimension_filter`:
          Example dimension_filter arguments:
      1. A simple filter:
        {"filter": {"field_name": "eventName", "string_filter": {"match_type": 2, "value": "add", "case_sensitive": false}}}

      2. A NOT filter:
        {"not_expression": {"filter": {"field_name": "eventName", "string_filter": {"match_type": 2, "value": "add", "case_sensitive": false}}}}

      3. An empty value filter:
        {"filter": {"field_name": "source", "empty_filter": {}}}

      4. An AND group filter:
        {"and_group": {"expressions": [{"filter": {"field_name": "sourceMedium", "string_filter": {"match_type": 1, "value": "google / cpc", "case_sensitive": false}}}, {"filter": {"field_name": "eventName", "in_list_filter": {"values": ["first_visit", "purchase", "add_to_cart"], "case_sensitive": true}}}]}}

      5. An OR group filter:
        {"or_group": {"expressions": [{"filter": {"field_name": "sourceMedium", "string_filter": {"match_type": 1, "value": "google / cpc", "case_sensitive": false}}}, {"filter": {"field_name": "eventName", "in_list_filter": {"values": ["first_visit", "purchase", "add_to_cart"], "case_sensitive": true}}}]}}

    
  Notes:
    The API applies the `dimension_filter` and `metric_filter`
    independently. As a result, some complex combinations of dimension and
    metric filters are not possible in a single report request.

    For example, you can't create a `dimension_filter` and `metric_filter`
    combination for the following condition:

    (
      (eventName = "page_view" AND eventCount > 100)
      OR
      (eventName = "join_group" AND eventCount < 50)
    )

    This isn't possible because there's no way to apply the condition
    "eventCount > 100" only to the data with eventName of "page_view", and
    the condition "eventCount < 50" only to the data with eventName of
    "join_group".

    More generally, you can't define a `dimension_filter` and `metric_filter`
    for:

    (
      ((dimension condition D1) AND (metric condition M1))
      OR
      ((dimension condition D2) AND (metric condition M2))
    )

    If you have complex conditions like this, either:

    a)  Run a single report that applies a subset of the conditions that
        the API supports as well as the data needed to perform filtering of the
        API response on the client side. For example, for the condition:
        (
          (eventName = "page_view" AND eventCount > 100)
          OR
          (eventName = "join_group" AND eventCount < 50)
        )
        You could run a report that filters only on:
        eventName one of "page_view" or "join_group"
        and include the eventCount metric, then filter the API response on the
        client side to apply the different metric filters for the different
        events.

    or

    b)  Run a separate report for each combination of dimension condition and
        metric condition. For the example above, you'd run one report for the
        combination of (D1 AND M1), and another report for the combination of
        (D2 AND M2).

    Try to run fewer reports (option a) if possible. However, if running
    fewer reports results in excessive quota usage for the API, use option
    b. More information on quota usage is at
    https://developers.google.com/analytics/blog/2023/data-api-quota-management.
  

          ### Hints for `metric_filter`:
          Example metric_filter arguments:
      1. A simple filter:
        {"filter": {"field_name": "eventCount", "numeric_filter": {"operation": 4, "value": {"int64_value": "10"}}}}

      2. A NOT filter:
        {"not_expression": {"filter": {"field_name": "eventCount", "numeric_filter": {"operation": 4, "value": {"int64_value": "10"}}}}}

      3. An empty value filter:
        {"filter": {"field_name": "purchaseRevenue", "empty_filter": {}}}

      4. An AND group filter:
        {"and_group": {"expressions": [{"filter": {"field_name": "eventCount", "numeric_filter": {"operation": 4, "value": {"int64_value": "10"}}}}, {"filter": {"field_name": "purchaseRevenue", "between_filter": {"from_value": {"double_value": 10.0}, "to_value": {"double_value": 25.0}}}}]}}

      5. An OR group filter:
        {"or_group": {"expressions": [{"filter": {"field_name": "eventCount", "numeric_filter": {"operation": 4, "value": {"int64_value": "10"}}}}, {"filter": {"field_name": "purchaseRevenue", "between_filter": {"from_value": {"double_value": 10.0}, "to_value": {"double_value": 25.0}}}}]}}

    
  Notes:
    The API applies the `dimension_filter` and `metric_filter`
    independently. As a result, some complex combinations of dimension and
    metric filters are not possible in a single report request.

    For example, you can't create a `dimension_filter` and `metric_filter`
    combination for the following condition:

    (
      (eventName = "page_view" AND eventCount > 100)
      OR
      (eventName = "join_group" AND eventCount < 50)
    )

    This isn't possible because there's no way to apply the condition
    "eventCount > 100" only to the data with eventName of "page_view", and
    the condition "eventCount < 50" only to the data with eventName of
    "join_group".

    More generally, you can't define a `dimension_filter` and `metric_filter`
    for:

    (
      ((dimension condition D1) AND (metric condition M1))
      OR
      ((dimension condition D2) AND (metric condition M2))
    )

    If you have complex conditions like this, either:

    a)  Run a single report that applies a subset of the conditions that
        the API supports as well as the data needed to perform filtering of the
        API response on the client side. For example, for the condition:
        (
          (eventName = "page_view" AND eventCount > 100)
          OR
          (eventName = "join_group" AND eventCount < 50)
        )
        You could run a report that filters only on:
        eventName one of "page_view" or "join_group"
        and include the eventCount metric, then filter the API response on the
        client side to apply the different metric filters for the different
        events.

    or

    b)  Run a separate report for each combination of dimension condition and
        metric condition. For the example above, you'd run one report for the
        combination of (D1 AND M1), and another report for the combination of
        (D2 AND M2).

    Try to run fewer reports (option a) if possible. However, if running
    fewer reports results in excessive quota usage for the API, use option
    b. More information on quota usage is at
    https://developers.google.com/analytics/blog/2023/data-api-quota-management.
  

          ### Hints for `order_bys`:
          Example order_bys arguments:

    1.  Order by ascending 'eventName':
        [ {"dimension": {"dimension_name": "eventName", "order_type": 1}, "desc": false} ]

    2.  Order by descending 'eventName', ignoring case:
        [ {"dimension": {"dimension_name": "campaignName", "order_type": 2}, "desc": true} ]

    3.  Order by ascending 'audienceId':
        [ {"dimension": {"dimension_name": "audienceId", "order_type": 3}, "desc": false} ]

    4.  Order by descending 'eventCount':
        [ {"metric": {"metric_name": "eventValue"}, "desc": true} ]

    5.  Order by ascending 'eventCount':
        [ {"metric": {"metric_name": "eventCount"}, "desc": false} ]

    6.  Combination of dimension and metric order bys:
        [
          {"dimension": {"dimension_name": "eventName", "order_type": 1}, "desc": false},
          {"metric": {"metric_name": "eventValue"}, "desc": true},
        ]

    7.  Order by multiple dimensions and metrics:
        [
          {"dimension": {"dimension_name": "eventName", "order_type": 1}, "desc": false},
          {"dimension": {"dimension_name": "audienceId", "order_type": 3}, "desc": false},
          {"metric": {"metric_name": "eventValue"}, "desc": true},
        ]

    The dimensions and metrics in order_bys must also be present in the report
    request's "dimensions" and "metrics" arguments, respectively.

subTools.name: List GA Accounts
subTools.description: Lists all Google Analytics accounts accessible to the user with their display names and IDs

subTools.name: List GA Properties
subTools.description: Lists all Google Analytics 4 properties with their IDs, names, and parent accounts. Property IDs are required for most other GA tools.

outputFields.name: property_id
outputFields.description: Full property ID (format: properties/123456) - use this for other GA tools

subTools.name: Get GA Property Details
subTools.description: Gets detailed configuration information for a GA4 property including timezone, currency, industry category, and service level

requiresFirst.reason: To get the property_id needed for this tool

inputs.name: property_id
inputs.description: The GA4 property ID to get details for

outputFields.name: currency_code
outputFields.description: Default currency (ISO 4217 format, e.g., EUR, USD)

subTools.name: List Google Ads Links
subTools.description: Lists all Google Ads accounts linked to a GA4 property, including customer IDs, personalization settings, and who created the link

requiresFirst.reason: To get the property_id needed for this tool

inputs.name: property_id
inputs.description: The GA4 property ID to list Google Ads links for

outputFields.name: link_name
outputFields.description: Full resource name of the Google Ads link

outputFields.name: customer_id
outputFields.description: Google Ads customer ID (10-digit number without dashes)

outputFields.name: ads_personalization_enabled
outputFields.description: Whether ads personalization is enabled for this link

outputFields.name: can_manage_clients
outputFields.description: Whether the linked account is a manager account

outputFields.name: creator_email
outputFields.description: Email of person who created the link

subTools.name: Get Custom Dimensions
subTools.description: Gets all custom dimensions defined for a GA4 property. Custom dimensions have api_name values that can be used in reports (e.g., customEvent:event_category, customUser:user_tier)

requiresFirst.reason: To get the property_id needed for this tool

inputs.name: property_id
inputs.description: The GA4 property ID to get custom dimensions for

outputFields.name: api_name
outputFields.description: API name to use in reports (e.g., customEvent:event_category)

outputFields.name: ui_name
outputFields.description: Display name shown in GA UI

outputExample.description: An event scoped custom dimension for your Analytics property.

subTools.name: Get Custom Metrics
subTools.description: Gets all custom metrics defined for a GA4 property. Custom metrics have api_name values that can be used in reports.

requiresFirst.reason: To get the property_id needed for this tool

inputs.name: property_id
inputs.description: The GA4 property ID to get custom metrics for

outputFields.name: api_name
outputFields.description: API name to use in reports

outputFields.name: ui_name
outputFields.description: Display name shown in GA UI

outputFields.name: measurement_unit
outputFields.description: Unit of measurement (STANDARD, CURRENCY, FEET, METERS, KILOMETERS, MILES, MILLISECONDS, SECONDS, MINUTES, HOURS)

subTools.name: Realtime Active Users by Country
subTools.description: Shows currently active users broken down by country - useful for monitoring live global traffic

requiresFirst.reason: To get the property_id needed for this tool

inputs.name: limit
inputs.description: Maximum number of countries to return

subTools.name: Realtime Active Users by Page
subTools.description: Shows which pages/screens have active users right now - useful for monitoring content engagement in real-time

requiresFirst.reason: To get the property_id needed for this tool

inputs.name: limit
inputs.description: Maximum number of pages to return

subTools.name: Realtime Events
subTools.description: Shows events happening in real-time with their counts - useful for monitoring conversions and user actions live

requiresFirst.reason: To get the property_id needed for this tool

inputs.name: limit
inputs.description: Maximum number of events to return

subTools.name: Realtime Trend by Minute
subTools.description: Shows active users and events per minute for the last 30 minutes - useful for spotting traffic spikes or drops

requiresFirst.reason: To get the property_id needed for this tool

subTools.name: Traffic Sources Report
subTools.description: Shows where your traffic comes from - sources, mediums, and channels with engagement metrics. Essential for understanding marketing effectiveness.

requiresFirst.reason: To get the property_id needed for this tool

subTools.name: Page Performance Report
subTools.description: Shows performance metrics for each page - sessions, bounce rate, and time on page. Essential for content optimization.

subTools.name: Geographic Report
subTools.description: Shows traffic and engagement by country - useful for understanding your global audience.

subTools.name: Device Category Report
subTools.description: Shows traffic and engagement by device type (desktop, mobile, tablet) - essential for responsive design decisions.

subTools.name: Events Report
subTools.description: Shows all events tracked on the property with counts and user engagement - essential for conversion tracking.

subTools.name: Daily Trend Report
subTools.description: Shows daily traffic trends over time - essential for spotting patterns, anomalies, and growth.

subTools.name: Landing Pages Report
subTools.description: Shows which pages users enter your site through - critical for SEO and campaign optimization.

subTools.name: Channel Performance Report
subTools.description: Shows traffic by default channel grouping (Organic Search, Paid Search, Social, Direct, etc.) - high-level marketing performance view.

subTools.name: User Acquisition Report
subTools.description: Shows how new users first discovered your site - focuses on first-touch attribution.

subTools.name: High Bounce Rate Pages
subTools.description: Identifies pages with high bounce rates that need optimization - filters for pages with significant traffic and bounce rate > 70%.

documentedInputs.description: This tool takes no inputs - it returns all accounts and properties accessible to the authenticated user
documentedInputs.notes: This is the foundational tool that provides property_id values needed by all other tools

source.description: First call get_account_summaries to get available property IDs
First call get_account_summaries to get available property IDs
First call get_account_summaries to get available property IDs
First call get_account_summaries to get available property IDs

options.description: Minutes ago (00-29) - for time-series realtime data

documentedInputs.notes: Realtime dimensions are LIMITED - different from regular report dimensions. Some combinations cannot be queried together (e.g., eventName + minutesAgo with activeUsers). User-scoped custom dimensions (customUser:*) from get_custom_dimensions_and_metrics can also be used.

options.description: Number of users currently active on the site/app

documentedInputs.notes: Realtime metrics are LIMITED. Custom metrics cannot be used in realtime reports. Some metric/dimension combinations are incompatible.

documentedInputs.description: Filter to apply to dimensions. Supports string_filter, in_list_filter, empty_filter with and_group, or_group, not_expression combinations

documentedInputs.format: FilterExpression object with numeric_filter or between_filter

documentedInputs.notes: order_type for dimensions: 1=ALPHANUMERIC, 2=CASE_INSENSITIVE_ALPHANUMERIC, 3=NUMERIC. Dimensions/metrics in order_bys must be in the report request.

documentedInputs.description: Maximum number of rows to return
documentedInputs.notes: Default varies. Use with offset for pagination.

documentedInputs.description: Row offset for pagination (first row is 0)
documentedInputs.notes: Use with limit for pagination through large result sets.
Useful for monitoring API usage limits

source.description: First call get_account_summaries to get available property IDs

documentedInputs.format: Array of DateRange objects with start_date, end_date, and optional name
documentedInputs.description: Date ranges for the report. Supports absolute dates (YYYY-MM-DD) and relative dates (today, yesterday, NdaysAgo)
documentedInputs.notes: When using multiple date ranges, a 'dateRange' dimension is automatically added to results. Max 4 date ranges per request.

options.description: Traffic medium for session (organic, cpc, referral, etc.)
Whether event is marked as conversion

documentedInputs.notes: This is a subset of common dimensions. Full list at https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/reporting/data/v1/api-schema#dimensions. Custom dimensions from get_custom_dimensions_and_metrics can also be used.

This is a subset of common metrics. Full list at https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/reporting/data/v1/api-schema#metrics. Custom metrics from get_custom_dimensions_and_metrics can also be used.

documentedInputs.format: FilterExpression object with numeric_filter or between_filter
documentedInputs.description: Filter to apply to metrics after aggregation
documentedInputs.notes: operation: 1=EQUAL, 2=LESS_THAN, 3=LESS_THAN_OR_EQUAL, 4=GREATER_THAN, 5=GREATER_THAN_OR_EQUAL. Cannot be combined with dimension_filter in complex AND/OR across both.
order_type for dimensions: 1=ALPHANUMERIC, 2=CASE_INSENSITIVE_ALPHANUMERIC, 3=NUMERIC. Dimensions/metrics must appear in the report request.
Use with offset for pagination. Default returns all rows up to 250,000.
Use with limit for pagination through large result sets.
Defaults to property's currency setting if not specified.

options.description: Include API quota usage in response

workflows.userTask: Which pages on my site are performing poorly and should be improved or removed?

steps.purpose: Get the property ID for the website to analyze
Find pages with bounce rate > 70% that have significant traffic
Get full performance context for all pages
Prioritize pages needing improvement based on traffic volume and bounce rate
steps.logic: Score each page: (bounce_rate * sessions) = impact_score. Higher score = more urgent fix needed. Pages with bounce > 85% and sessions > 100 are critical.

workflows.answerTemplate: Found {count} underperforming pages. Priority fixes: 1) {page1} - {sessions1} sessions, {bounce1}% bounce rate. 2) {page2} - {sessions2} sessions, {bounce2}% bounce. Recommendation: Review content relevance, page load speed, and mobile experience for these pages.
decisionPoints: If bounce rate > 90% and sessions > 50, recommend content audit or removal
If bounce rate 70-90% and engagement < 20%, recommend UX improvements
If page has high traffic but low engagement, check if it matches search intent

workflows.userTask: How does my traffic this month compare to last month? What changed and why?

steps.purpose: Get available properties
Get daily trends for current period
Get daily trends for previous period
Get traffic sources for current period to identify what's driving changes
Get traffic sources for previous period for comparison
Calculate period-over-period changes and identify biggest movers
steps.logic: Sum sessions/users for each period. Calculate % change. Compare source/medium performance between periods to find which channels grew or declined most.

workflows.answerTemplate: Traffic comparison: Current period had {current_sessions} sessions vs {previous_sessions} last period ({change_pct}% change). Biggest changes: {source1} {direction1} by {change1}%, {source2} {direction2} by {change2}%. This suggests {analysis}.
decisionPoints: If organic traffic dropped > 20%, investigate SEO issues or algorithm updates
If paid traffic dropped but organic grew, evaluate if this is intentional budget shift
If direct traffic spiked, look for PR mentions or email campaigns
If referral traffic changed significantly, identify which referring sites

workflows.userTask: Which traffic source is bringing me the best quality visitors? Where should I invest more?

steps.purpose: Get available properties
Get all traffic sources with engagement metrics
Get channel-level view for strategic planning
Rank traffic sources by quality score combining engagement and volume
steps.logic: Quality Score = (engagement_rate * 0.4) + (avg_session_duration_normalized * 0.3) + (pages_per_session_normalized * 0.3). Efficiency Score = Quality Score / cost (if paid). Rank sources by quality for organic, by efficiency for paid.

workflows.answerTemplate: Best quality traffic sources: 1) {source1}/{medium1} with {engagement1}% engagement, {duration1}s avg duration. 2) {source2}/{medium2} with {engagement2}% engagement. Recommendation: Increase investment in {best_source} which has {quality_description}. Consider reducing spend on {worst_source} which has only {worst_engagement}% engagement.
decisionPoints: If organic has highest engagement but low volume, invest in SEO content
If paid has high volume but low engagement, optimize ad targeting or landing pages
If referral traffic has high engagement, pursue more partnerships with those sites
If social has low engagement, review content strategy for social channels

workflows.userTask: Is my website performing well on mobile devices? Should I prioritize mobile optimization?

steps.purpose: Get available properties
Get performance breakdown by device category
Check if device issues vary by geography (mobile-first markets)
Calculate mobile performance gap and business impact
steps.logic: Mobile Gap = desktop_engagement_rate - mobile_engagement_rate. If gap > 15%, significant mobile UX issues. Calculate lost_sessions = mobile_sessions * mobile_gap as opportunity cost.

workflows.answerTemplate: Device breakdown: Desktop {desktop_pct}% of traffic with {desktop_engagement}% engagement. Mobile {mobile_pct}% of traffic with {mobile_engagement}% engagement. Mobile performance gap: {gap}%. {recommendation}
decisionPoints: If mobile traffic > 50% but engagement < desktop by 20%+, urgent mobile optimization needed
If mobile bounce rate > 70%, check page load speed and mobile UX
If mobile sessions growing but engagement declining, site may not be keeping up with mobile traffic growth
If tablet has worst performance, may indicate responsive design breakpoint issues

workflows.userTask: What's happening on my website right now? Is there any unusual activity?

steps.purpose: Get available properties
See where current visitors are located
See what pages visitors are viewing now
Check for traffic spikes or drops in last 30 minutes
See what actions users are taking right now
Identify anomalies or noteworthy patterns
steps.logic: Compare current active users to typical levels. Flag if traffic > 2x normal or < 0.5x normal. Check if traffic is concentrated in unusual geography or on unexpected pages.

workflows.answerTemplate: Right now: {active_users} active users. Top locations: {top_countries}. Most viewed pages: {top_pages}. Traffic trend: {trend_description}. Notable: {anomalies_or_insights}.
decisionPoints: If traffic spike from single country, may indicate bot traffic or viral content
If specific page has unusual traffic, check for social media mentions or news coverage
If traffic suddenly dropped, check for site outages or tracking issues
If conversion events spiking, a campaign may be performing exceptionally well

workflows.userTask: Which landing pages should I optimize first to improve conversions?

steps.purpose: Get available properties
Get all landing pages with performance metrics
Understand which sources drive traffic to prioritize paid vs organic landing pages
Calculate optimization priority score for each landing page
steps.logic: Priority Score = sessions * (1 - engagement_rate). Higher score = more potential improvement. Filter for pages with sessions > 50 to focus on meaningful volume. Flag pages with paid traffic and bounce > 60% as urgent (wasting ad spend).

workflows.answerTemplate: Top landing pages to optimize: 1) {page1} - {sessions1} sessions, {bounce1}% bounce (potential: {potential1} recovered sessions). 2) {page2} - {sessions2} sessions, {bounce2}% bounce. Quick wins: {quick_wins}. For paid traffic landing pages, prioritize: {paid_priorities}.
decisionPoints: If landing page bounce > 80%, check page relevance to traffic source
If organic landing page performs poorly, may indicate content-keyword mismatch
If paid landing page has high bounce, check ad copy alignment with page content
If homepage is top landing page with high bounce, consider adding clearer CTAs

workflows.userTask: Am I getting enough new visitors? How well am I retaining existing users?

steps.purpose: Get available properties
See how new users are being acquired
Track new vs total users over time to see retention trends
See which channels bring new users vs returning
Calculate acquisition health metrics
steps.logic: New User Ratio = new_users / total_users. Healthy range is 40-70% depending on business model. If > 80%, not retaining users. If < 30%, not growing audience. Calculate retention_proxy = (total_users - new_users) / total_users.

workflows.answerTemplate: User acquisition analysis: {new_users} new users ({new_pct}% of total). Returning users: {returning_users} ({returning_pct}%). Top acquisition channels: {top_channels}. Trend: {trend_analysis}. Assessment: {health_assessment}.
decisionPoints: If new user ratio > 85%, focus on engagement and retention strategies
If new user ratio < 30%, increase top-of-funnel marketing investment
If returning user engagement is low, review email marketing and remarketing
If specific channel has high new user % but low engagement, targeting may be too broad

workflows.userTask: Which countries or regions should I focus on for expansion? Where is my untapped potential?

steps.purpose: Get available properties
Get traffic and engagement by country
Understand device preferences to inform localization strategy
Check current property timezone and currency settings
Identify high-potential markets for expansion
steps.logic: Opportunity Score = engagement_rate * (1 / market_saturation_proxy). Markets with high engagement but lower traffic have growth potential. Flag countries with traffic > 100 sessions and engagement > 50% as high-potential. Consider mobile-first for emerging markets.

workflows.answerTemplate: Geographic analysis: Top markets by volume: {top_volume_countries}. Highest engagement markets: {top_engagement_countries}. Expansion opportunities (high engagement, room to grow): {opportunity_markets}. Recommendation: {expansion_recommendation}.
decisionPoints: If a country has high engagement but low traffic, consider localized content or ads
If emerging markets show high mobile %, ensure mobile-optimized experience
If a country has high traffic but low engagement, investigate content relevance
If engagement varies significantly by country, consider regional landing pages

workflows.userTask: How effective are my marketing campaigns? Which ones should I scale or stop?

steps.purpose: Get available properties
Check if Google Ads is linked for paid campaign data
Get all traffic sources including campaign traffic
Get channel-level performance for budget allocation decisions
Rank campaigns by effectiveness and ROI potential
steps.logic: Effectiveness Score = (engagement_rate * 0.5) + (conversions_per_session * 0.5). Compare paid channels (cpc, paid) vs organic. Flag paid sources with engagement < 20% as potential waste. Identify top performers for scaling.

workflows.answerTemplate: Campaign effectiveness: Paid traffic: {paid_sessions} sessions, {paid_engagement}% engagement, {paid_conversions} conversions. Organic: {organic_sessions} sessions, {organic_engagement}% engagement. Best performing: {best_campaign}. Underperforming: {worst_campaign}. Recommendation: {budget_recommendation}.
decisionPoints: If paid engagement < 20% while organic > 50%, improve ad targeting or landing pages
If specific source/medium has high conversions, increase budget allocation
If Google Ads linked but CPC engagement low, review keyword targeting
If referral traffic has high engagement, pursue partnership opportunities

workflows.userTask: Which content is performing best? What topics should I create more of?

steps.purpose: Get available properties
Get all pages with engagement metrics
See which content attracts organic entry traffic
See what actions users take (scrolls, clicks, shares)
Identify content patterns and top performers
steps.logic: Content Score = (sessions * engagement_rate * avg_time_on_page). Group pages by URL pattern to identify topic clusters. Top scorers indicate successful topics. Low scorers with high traffic indicate missed opportunities.

workflows.answerTemplate: Content audit results: Top performing pages: {top_pages}. Best engagement: {best_engagement_pages}. Content patterns: {patterns}. Topics to create more of: {recommended_topics}. Content to update: {update_candidates}.
decisionPoints: If /blog/ pages outperform others, invest more in content marketing
If product pages have low engagement, add more compelling content or CTAs
If specific topic cluster performs well, create more related content
If old content still gets traffic but low engagement, update and refresh it

workflows.userTask: Give me an overall health check of my website's analytics - what's working and what needs attention?

steps.purpose: Get available properties
Get property configuration details
Get traffic trends to assess overall trajectory
Assess channel mix health
Check device performance parity
Identify problem pages
Generate overall health score and recommendations
steps.logic: Health Score components: Traffic Trend (growing/stable/declining), Channel Diversity (not over-reliant on one source), Device Parity (mobile vs desktop gap < 20%), Engagement Health (overall engagement > 40%), Problem Pages (< 20% of traffic to high-bounce pages). Score 0-100.

decisionPoints: If traffic declining > 10% month-over-month, urgent investigation needed
If single channel > 60% of traffic, diversification recommended
If mobile engagement < 50% of desktop, mobile optimization critical
If overall engagement < 30%, review content strategy and UX

insights: This MCP provides comprehensive access to Google Analytics 4 data through 6 core tools. The foundational tool is get_account_summaries which provides property IDs needed by all other tools. The two main reporting tools are run_report (historical data with 200+ dimensions/metrics) and run_realtime_report (live data with limited ~15 dimensions/metrics). Key discoveries: (1) Realtime reports have a restricted dimension/metric set - many standard dimensions like firstUserSource don't work; (2) Some dimension/metric combinations are incompatible and will error; (3) Multiple date ranges automatically add a dateRange dimension for comparison; (4) The API uses snake_case for field names not camelCase; (5) Filters use numeric codes for operations (1=EQUAL, 4=GREATER_THAN, etc.) and match types (1=EXACT, 2=BEGINS_WITH, etc.). The most valuable sub-tools focus on common analytics questions: traffic sources, page performance, device breakdown, geographic distribution, and landing page analysis. Workflows enable complex multi-step analyses like comparing time periods, identifying underperforming content, mobile optimization decisions, and comprehensive site health checks.
